poem:
Title: Upon Reading Today's News

Oh, the political pirouette,
Azhar Ali's fateful silhouette.
Where once was tact, now there's regret,
the words we type, the traps we set.

Morning paper's ink still wet,
a story scribed, a scene reset.
Past regrets we won't forget,
in elections lost and bets unmet.

Out there in Rochdale, a silhouette,
Ali and his great regret.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Labour criticised for backing Rochdale candidate after offensive Israel remark Labour is facing criticism for standing by a parliamentary candidate who has been forced to apologise for suggesting that Israel allowed Hamas’s 7 October attacks to take place to provide grounds to invade Gaza. The comments made by Azhar Ali, the party’s candidate in the Rochdale byelection, have threatened to reignite the damaging row over antisemitism in the Labour party that blighted Jeremy Corbyn’s leadership. “This". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
